A Character improves over time based on the actions they take and the choices made for them by the player.

Improvement

The basic means of improving Skills and Abilities is use. Each time a skill is attempted they have a chance of recieving experience towards the improvement of that skill.

  • Improving an ability requires XP equal to the new level times 10.
  • Improving a skill requires XP equal to three times the new level.
  • Improving a skill specialization requires Xp equal to the new level.

Improvement Implementation

Gaining Experience

People learn the most in the least likely occurrance, and they learn at all only when at the edges of their ability. Thus a novice generally learns from his limited successes and near successes while a master generally has little to learn from success and much to learn from failures and near-failures.

Most uses of skills are performed by taking (Own ability * Own skill) minus (Opponent's Ability * Opp skill) to determine a percentage chance of success. Occassionally, if the roll is close to the target number, the character will learn something- they gain an experience point towards improving that skill. This "window" is 10% of the character's chance of the opposite event.
Thus, a character with a 50% chance of success will gain a point of experience to improve that Skill or Ability on a 45-55% roll. A character with a 60% chance, however, learns something on a roll of 56-66%. Characters who have a 0% chance of success learn something on a 1-10%, while a greater than 100% chance of success at a task completely negates any chance of learning (no roll will yield Xp).

The experience point is automatically applied to whichever part has fewer experience points- thus a character with a 3 Strength (60-99 Xp) and 9 Unarmed skill (45-54 Xp) would apply the experience towards the Unarmed skill. If both the Ability and the skill are tied for least experience the skill is improved. If a point is contributed towards the skill an extra experience point is generated towards the appropriate specialization (if any exists).

Experience Implementation

Derived Statistic Improvement

A character's Abilities can improve through using resources such as Hit Points, Stamina, and Willpower. Each time a character regains a point in one of these resources they have a percentage chance of granting a point of experience to the Ability from which it is derived. This chance is 10% divided by any multiplier to the Ability which is used to derive the statistic. Thus, each Hit Point regained grants a 10% chance of improvement while each point of Stamina regained comes with a 1% chance of gaining experience.

Derived Stat Improvement Implementation

Hobbies

A character may have up to 3 hobbies listed. Each hour they are logged in and active they will gain at least 20 experience points. If they do not gain this many experience points through skill checks made by their game-actions or training during the hour the remaining points are distributed among the chosen hobbies in descending order. (If no experience points are gained through skill use the 20 experience points should be distributed 11, 6, 3)

Hobby Implementation

Training

Characters with the Teacher skill can sometimes provide others with Experience towards improving their skills.

Limited Skills

Some skills, such as Teacher are limited by other skills- being replaced if the other skill is lower. Such instances do not cause experience to be generated for that replacement skill. If a roll would indicate an increase in experience the skill by which the check is initiated gains that experience, not the alternate, is subject to the improvement.

Limited Skills Implementation

Depriciation

A character's ability with skills that go unused and unpracticed will erode. This is covered in more detail on the Skills page.
